attributes.title: The impact of formal explanations on kindhood and essentialism

q1.value: Property type and formal explanations on kindhood and essentialism

q3.value: Version of Noyes & Keil, 2019 study 2 adapted for formal explanations. Since the structure of formal explanations on their own doesn't reliably increase essentialism, are there conditions under which formal explanations do increase essentialism? In this study, we investigate whether the type of property explained affects whether formal explanations increase essentialism, namely whether formal explanations of biological properties increase essentialism.

q4.value: 3-way interaction between condition (formal vs control), property type (biological vs cultural), measure (kind vs essence). Formal explanations will increase essentialism more when they explain a biological property, compared to a cultural property. Formal explanations will increase kindhood (relative to control statements) whether biological or cultural properties are used.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants are randomly assigned to one of 3 statement conditions - formal explanations, generics, or specific control wording - and one of 2 property type conditions - biological or cultural.

Participants read statements worded in their given condition about properties of a novel social category, Zarpies. These statements are drawn from Noyes & Keil, 2019 (which in turn is drawn from Rhodes, Leslie & Tworek, 2012), and presented with novel proper names for formal explanations and control statements, and presented without accompanying pictures. 

Lastly, participants then receive measures of kindhood (excluding formal explanations felicity) and essentialism drawn from Noyes & Keil, 2019 study 1.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Adults recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk using TurkPrime who are located in the US, over 18 years of age, and have at least a 98% approval rate.

q13.value: We will aim for 300 participants total, 50 in each of the 3 x 2 conditions.

question.value: Participants in the formal explanation condition will read formal explanations of the form "[Proper name].... because she/he is a Zarpie." Participants in the generics condition will read generic statements of the form "Zarpies....". Participants in the specific control condition will read specific variations of the generic statements of the form "This Zarpie, named [proper name],....".

We will use 3 measures of kindhood (inherent similarity, heterogeneous [reverse-coded], inductive potential) and 4 measures of essentialism (internal cause, constructed category [reverse-coded], constructed boundaries [reverse-coded], immutability) borrowed directly from Noyes & Keil, 2019.
Each measure is a 6-point Likert scale that will be coded 0-1 (or 1-0 for reverse-coded measures) in evenly spaced intervals, and will be averaged into an overall measure of kindhood or essentialism.

Linear mixed effects model with condition (formal explanation, specific), property type (biological, cultural), measure (kind, essence), and their 3-way interaction, with participant as a random intercept.

q22.value: Participants who fail the attention check (don't select that this study involved "Learning about Zarpies and answering multiple choice questions about them") will be excluded. We'll also exclude participants who fail an additional attention check after the removal of the pictures (don't select at least 3 out of the target 4 properties).

q24.value: Replication of Noyes & Keil, 2019 study 2 finding that generics (compared to specific wording) increase kindhood more so than essentialism, and that generics increase essentialism more so for biological properties than cultural properties. Formal explanations to show weaker kind and essentialism effects than generics.

q25.value: Study design and stimuli drawn from Noyes & Keil, 2019, PNAS, study 2, with pictures removed and novel proper names substituted.

attributes.title: Geodatabase
attributes.description: Geospatial data for the Rio Grande/Río Bravo socio-environmental system

summary.value:
The database was peer-reviewed and the corresponding manuscript was published as:
Plassin, S.; Koch, J.; Paladino, S.; Friedman, J.R.; Spencer, K.; Vaché, K. (2020) A socio-environmental geodatabase for integrative research in the transboundary Rio Grande/Rio Bravo basin. Scientific Data 7:80.

registration_responses.summary:
The database was peer-reviewed and the corresponding manuscript was published as:
Plassin, S.; Koch, J.; Paladino, S.; Friedman, J.R.; Spencer, K.; Vaché, K. (2020) A socio-environmental geodatabase for integrative research in the transboundary Rio Grande/Rio Bravo basin. Scientific Data 7:80.

attributes.title: Long-Term Self-Compassion Interventions and Health Goal Adherence

q1.value: Long-Term Self-Compassion Interventions and Health Goal Adherence

q3.value: The purpose of the present study is explore a way to assist individuals who would like to make a health behavior change, such as eating a healthier diet. Often times, health behavior change results in failures which can be discouraging and make the person experience negative emotions resulting in them abandoning their health goals. Self-compassion, a technique of treating oneself with the same compassion one would treat others, provides a potential countermeasure to these negative emotions that can prevent a person from reaching their goals. If a person who has failed to adhere to their health goals engages in self-compassion (via a self-compassion meditation) they may be more likely to forgive themselves for making a mistake and continue striving toward their health goals. To test this theory, we will recruit participants to engage in long-term self-compassion meditations (20 minutes, 5 days per week for 3 weeks) in order to test their efficacy as potential inductions that could be used to facilitate health behavior changes.

q4.value:
1. Participants assigned to self-compassion meditations will report greater levels of self-compassion and greater health goal success over the course of the study than those assigned to mindfulness meditations. 
2. Participants assigned to self-compassion meditations will report lower levels of negative affect daily than those assigned to mindfulness meditations. 
3. Participants assigned to self-compassion meditations will report higher levels of self-efficacy to pursue their health goal again on the following day than those assigned to mindfulness meditations.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Data will be analyzed using hierarchical linear modeling techniques with time nested within person.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through a university subject pool website where they will be granted course credit or extra credit for participation. Participants who complete 10/15 daily diary surveys will also be entered to win one of 40 $50 Amazon gift cards. Participants must be 18 years or older and English-speaker. Surveys will be administered in-lab (intake) and via email (daily) using Qualtrics.
We will manipulate the induction people experience with 2 levels: self-compassion audio induces or control audio inductions (mindfulness meditation)
We will measure mindfulness level, self-compassion level, affect, goal adherence, and efficacy for the health goal participants are pursuing.
We will use Hierarchical Linear Modeling with time nested within person to analyze our data.

q22.value: Data will be excluded from participants who do not spend an adequate amount of time with daily survey (to be determined from distribution of timing when data is analyzed, outliers will be eliminated).

q23.value: Composite scores will be calculated in the case of missing data points for each outcome measure.

If a person who has failed to adhere to their health goals engages in self-compassion (via a self-compassion meditation) they may be more likely to forgive themselves for making a mistake and continue striving toward their health goals. To test this theory, we will recruit participants to engage in long-term self-compassion meditations (20 minutes, 5 days per week for 3 weeks) in order to test their efficacy as potential inductions that could be used to facilitate health behavior changes.

attributes.title: E-Cigarette Gain and Loss Framed Health Messages

q1.value: Impact of Gain and Loss Framed Health Messages on E-Cigarette Attitudes and Intentions - Study 3

q2.value: Antonia N Santoro, John Updegraff, Karigan Capps

q3.value: Previous research has explored gain-framed and loss-framed health messages in a variety of contexts, including traditional cigarette use. While traditional cigarettes are well understood as detrimental to individual and public health, electronic cigarettes have not been as well researched, and the health impacts are not well-established. Therefore, this study will explore the impact of gain- and loss-framed messages on opinions about and intentions for future e-cigarette use in young adults. We have completed study 1 and study 2 investigating this question but found our manipulations ineffective.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Framing Effects 
a. Gain framed messages will result in (1) more positive perceptions of the message, (2) more positive perceptions of the source, (3) lower message reactance, (4) lower intentions to use e-cigarettes, (5) greater efficacy to avoid e-cigarettes in the future and (6) greater time spent with e-cigarette cessation resources for participants who have pre-existing intentions to their quit e-cigarette use. 

Hypothesis 2: Optimism effects 
a. Those higher in optimism who view the loss-framed message will report higher self-efficacy and intentions to avoid using e-cigs. 
b. Those lower in optimism who view the gain-framed message will report higher self-efficacy and intentions to avoid using e-cigs. 

Hypothesis 3: Message processing
a. Those higher in optimism will recall more information from the flyers than those lower in optimism. 
b. Those lower in optimism will be less likely to opt to receive more information about the effects of using e-cigarettes.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We have a between subjects design with 1 factor (message framing) with 2 levels (gain- vs. loss-framed).

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned using Qualtrics's randomization feature at the participant level.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through a university subject pool website where they will be granted course credit or extra credit for participation. Participants must be 18 years or older and English-speaking. Surveys will be administered online via Qualtrics.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 128 based on a power analysis in G*Power. We will recruit up to 300 participants, assuming that not all participants will pass all attention checks, as the study will be administered online.

q14.value: We used G*Power to conduct our power analysis. Our goal is to obtain .80 power and detect a medium effect size of f = .25 (d = .5) at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value: We will manipulate message framing with 2 levels: gain framed messages or loss framed messages.

We will measure perception of the health message, perception of the source of the message, reactance, intentions to quit e-cigarette use, efficacy to avoid using e-cigarettes in the future, and time spent with e-cigarette cessation resources.

Additional variables of interest to be measured include: mindfulness, self-compassion, optimism, need for cognition, reasons for e-cigarette use, perceptions of e-cigarette impact on health, and susceptibility to e-cigarette health and social outcomes.

We will use a multiple regression (with interactions) to analyze our data.  The independent variable will be message framing and our dependent variables will be perception of the health message, perception of the source of the message, reactance, intentions to quit e-cigarette use, perceptions of e-cigarette impact on health, efficacy to avoid using e-cigarettes in the future, and time spent with e-cigarette cessation resources.

q22.value: Data will be excluded from participants who do not pass an attention check contained within the survey.

q23.value: Composite scores will be calculated even in the case of missing data point for each outcome measure.

q24.value: We will explore trait mindfulness, trait self-compassion as potential individual differences that influence the relationship between framing and outcomes. We will also measure need for cognition, reasons for e-cigarette use, perceptions of e-cigarette impact on health, and susceptibility to e-cigarette health and social outcomes.

registration_responses.q1: Impact of Gain and Loss Framed Health Messages on E-Cigarette Attitudes and Intentions - Study 3
registration_responses.q2: Antonia N Santoro, John Updegraff, Karigan Capps

While traditional cigarettes are well understood as detrimental to individual and public health, electronic cigarettes have not been as well researched, and the health impacts are not well-established. Therefore, this study will explore the impact of gain- and loss-framed messages on opinions about and intentions for future e-cigarette use in young adults. We have completed study 1 and study 2 investigating this question but found our manipulations ineffective.

Hypothesis 1: Framing Effects 
a. Gain framed messages will result in (1) more positive perceptions of the message, (2) more positive perceptions of the source, (3) lower message reactance, (4) lower intentions to use e-cigarettes, (5) greater efficacy to avoid e-cigarettes in the future and (6) greater time spent with e-cigarette cessation resources for participants who have pre-existing intentions to their quit e-cigarette use. 

Hypothesis 2: Optimism effects 
a. Those higher in optimism who view the loss-framed message will report higher self-efficacy and intentions to avoid using e-cigs. 
b. Those lower in optimism who view the gain-framed message will report higher self-efficacy and intentions to avoid using e-cigs. 

Hypothesis 3: Message processing
a. Those higher in optimism will recall more information from the flyers than those lower in optimism. 
b. Those lower in optimism will be less likely to opt to receive more information about the effects of using e-cigarettes.

q1.value: Attachment Security Priming and Resource Sharing

q2.value: Parnia Haj-Mohamadi, Omri Gillath, Ali Imran

q3.value:
Resource sharing is a pro-social behavior related to phenomena such as altruism and helping (e.g., Keltner, Kogan, Piff, & Satum, 2014; Knafo & Israel, 2012), which have been studied extensively (e.g., Batson, 2011; Piliavin & Charng, 1990; Schroeder, Penner, Dovidio, & Piliavin, 1995). The current work builds on previous research on the associations between pro-social tendencies and attachment style—a well-studied individual difference—and on the enhancement of prosocial behavior via attachment security (Gillath & Karantzas, 2015). 

Past work about attachment and its enhancement has revealed that attachment insecurity and especially avoidance is associated with a decreased tendency to engage in pro-social behaviors; whereas attachment anxiety was only associated with motives for volunteering but not with the actual behavior or behavioral tendencies (Gillath et al., 2005). Enhancing one’s sense of security was found to increase other-oriented pro-social tendencies and behaviors (Mikulincer et al., 2005), which suggests that attachment security gives rise to a general increase in prosocial tendency. Based on these findings, we hypothesized that security primes would lead to increases in resource sharing compared to insecurity or neutral primes.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Attachment security priming will lead to increases in resource sharing compared to avoidance and neutral primes.

Hypothesis 2: Attachment avoidant priming will result in a decrease in resource sharing compared to the security prime and control group.

Exploratory Hypothesis: We plan to conduct a mediation analysis with affect as a mediator variable for the relationship between prime type (predictor) and resource sharing amount (outcome). We predict that the relationship between attachment priming and sharing resources is unique to attachment style and thus will not be mediated by positive/negative affect. 

We expect a significant effect of prime (secure, avoidant, and neutral) on resource sharing amount (monetary value given to partner), where security primes are predicted to lead to an increase in resource sharing, while avoidance primes are predicted to lead to a decrease in resource sharing compared to all conditions.

We will use the State Adult Attachment Measure (SAAM; Gillath, Hart, Noftle, & Stockdale, 2009) as a manipulation check of the attachment primes (i.e., security and avoidance).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In order to test our confirmatory hypotheses, a one-way between-subjects ANOVA will be conducted with prime type (security, avoidance, neutral) as the fixed factor and resource sharing as the dependent variable, measured by the average monetary value given to interactive partners across all 80 trials.

In order to test our exploratory hypothesis that affect mediates the relationship between attachment primes and resource sharing, we will conduct a mediation model using PROCESS (Model 4) with affect as the mediator, prime as the predictor, and resource sharing as the outcome variable. 

Potential covariates include the following constructs listed below—and will be controlled for in analyses:
1.	Positive and negative affect 
2.	Self-esteem 
3.	Personality 
4.	Trait Attachment Style 
5.	Donation History
6.	Gender
7.	Age

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected from undergraduate students at the University of Kansas enrolled in an introductory psychology course via SONA online systems. Data collection is expected to begin in February, 2018 and conclude at the end of semester in May, 2018.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 158 participants to achieve 80% power.

q14.value: A power analysis was conducted using G*Power 3.1 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007; ANCOVA F-test, f = .25, numerator df = 2, number of groups = 3, α = .05. 1 – β = .80), and plan to aim for a sample size of at least 158 participants, with at least 53 participants per condition.

question.value: We manipulated attachment style by subliminally priming words associated with attachment security (e.g., love, dependable), attachment insecurity (e.g., withdraw, detach), or neutral primes (e.g., lamp, whistle).
The single outcome variable is the amount of money given to partners (i.e., sum of dollars). This will be measured across 80 trials in an economic decision-making task using e-prime.

An ANCOVA will be conducted to test the main effect of independent variable, i.e., priming, while controlling for existing attachment style (and all other covariates). Planned comparisons between secure and avoidant, secure and neutral, and avoidant and neutral conditions will also be made to test confirmatory hypotheses.

q23.value: Missing data will be handled using pair-wise deletion. Reliability criteria for item inclusion should be at least .70.

registration_responses.q2: Parnia Haj-Mohamadi, Omri Gillath, Ali Imran

The current work builds on previous research on the associations between pro-social tendencies and attachment style—a well-studied individual difference—and on the enhancement of prosocial behavior via attachment security (Gillath & Karantzas, 2015).

Enhancing one’s sense of security was found to increase other-oriented pro-social tendencies and behaviors (Mikulincer et al., 2005), which suggests that attachment security gives rise to a general increase in prosocial tendency. registration_responses.q12.question: Data will be collected from undergraduate students at the University of Kansas enrolled in an introductory psychology course via SONA online systems. Data collection is expected to begin in February, 2018 and conclude at the end of semester in May, 2018.
registration_responses.q16.question: We manipulated attachment style by subliminally priming words associated with attachment security (e.g., love, dependable), attachment insecurity (e.g., withdraw, detach), or neutral primes (e.g., lamp, whistle).
registration_responses.q17.question: The single outcome variable is the amount of money given to partners (i.e., sum of dollars). This will be measured across 80 trials in an economic decision-making task using e-prime.
registration_responses.q19.question: An ANCOVA will be conducted to test the main effect of independent variable, i.e., priming, while controlling for existing attachment style (and all other covariates). Planned comparisons between secure and avoidant, secure and neutral, and avoidant and neutral conditions will also be made to test confirmatory hypotheses.

attributes.title: A Frugal Innovation Approach to Dynamic Electricity Pricing in Rural India: A Field Experiment

q1.value: A Frugal Innovation Approach to Dynamic Electricity Pricing in Rural India: A Field Experiment

q2.value: Semee Yoon | Sini Numminen | Peter Lund

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q16.value: Hypothesis 1. Relative to the static mode, in dynamic mode households consume less electricity. Hypothesis 2. Relative to the static mode, in dynamic mode households experience fewer technical problems. Hypothesis 3. Relative to the static mode, in dynamic mode households improve customer satisfaction. Hypothesis 4. Relative to the static mode, in dynamic mode the solar fraction is higher.

q17.value: Linear regressions of treatment effects on outcomes based on survey and technical data.

attributes.title: Influence of information about Coronavirus (COVID-19) in news media on prejudice towards foreign nationalities, especially Chinese people

q1.value: Influence of information about Coronavirus (COVID-19) in news media on prejudice towards foreign nationalities, especially Chinese people.

q2.value: Michał Białek, Agata Groyecka, Maciej Karwowski, Marta Kowal, Izabela Lebuda, Agnieszka Sorokowska, Piotr Sorokowski, Przemysław Zdybek

q3.value: We intend to investigate how information about Coronavirus (COVID-19) – depicted in mass media – influences prejudice towards foreign nationalities, especially Chinese people.

q4.value: Main hypothesis: The frequency of receiving information about Coronavirus (COVID-19) from news media influences prejudice towards the Chinese and Italians.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Between subject design. 

All participants will be invited to take part in two (allegedly) independent studies.
The first study includes the frequency of mass media attendance (e.g., TV viewership, news browsing, and Internet usage), and the second study includes a short questionnaire regarding the prejudices towards four nationalities.

At the end, participants will provide information regarding basic socio-economic measures.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
All participants will be recruited with the help of an external survey company. Participants will be compensated for the participation.

After agreeing to take part in the study, participants will be presented with questions regarding the mass media attendance (i.e. frequency of, e.g., TV viewership, media browsing, and Internet usage).

In the second part of the study, participants will provide answers on their attitudes towards the four nationalities (i.e. Hungarian, Italian, Mongolian, and Chinese), presented in a random order. 

A short questionnaire about basic socio-economic measures will be placed at the end of the study.

q14.value: Using G*Power we determined that we need 193 participants in order to obtain a power of 80%, with alpha .05 to detect a medium size effect of r =.2 (two-tailed). We will overshoot this number due to expected missing data.

question.value: No manipulation will be implemented in the present study.

We will collect data regarding the frequency of participants’ general mass media attendance. The questionnaire will include the following questions:

On an average day, how much time do you spend on: 
1.	watching a TV? [number] hours a day.
2.	using the Internet? [number] hours a day.
3.	listening radio? [number] hours a day.
In particular:
4.	watching movies? [number] hours a day.
5.	playing video games? [number] hours a day.
6.	browsing, reading or listening the news? [number] hours a day.
7.	communicating with other people through the Internet? [number] hours a day.
8.	listening to music? [number] hours a day.
We will sum the reported amount of hours during which participants may came across news about Coronavirus (i.e. browsing, reading or listening the news) to obtain a single score of exposition to the potential news regarding Coronavirus.

We will measure attitudes towards four nationalities (i.e. Hungarian, Italian, Mongolian, and Chinese), using Bogardus (1925; 1933) scale, which consists of three questions (i.e. whether participants would accept a member of a given group as a co-worker, as a neighbor, and as part of their family). Responses range from 1 (‘definitely wouldn’t mind’) to 7 (‘definitely would mind’). There will be, in total nine questions (three questions per each nationality):

Would you mind if an Italian was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Italians were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married an Italian? 

Would you mind if a Hungarian was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Hungarians were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married a Hungarian? 

Would you mind if a Chinese was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Chinese people were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married a Chinese? 

Would you mind if a Mongolian was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Mongolians people were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married a Mongolian?


The order of the presented nationalities will be randomized.

We will average the scores across the three questions to obtain a single measure of prejudice towards the Hungarians, Italians, Mongolians, and the Chinese.

We will use correlation to investigate the relationship between prejudices towards the four nationalities: the Hungarian, Italian, Mongolian, and Chinese, and the frequency of information about Coronavirus (COVID-19) in news media.

q24.value: We will exploratorily examine the correlation between the media exposure and prejudice toward Mongolians and Hungarians.

attributes.title: Influence of Coronavirus (COVID-19) on prejudice towards the Chinese and other nations

q1.value: Influence of Coronavirus (COVID-19) on prejudice towards the Chinese and other nations.

q2.value: Michał Białek, Agata Groyecka, Maciej Karwowski, Marta Kowal, Izabela Lebuda, Agnieszka Sorokowska, Piotr Sorokowski, Przemysław Zdybek

q3.value: We intend to investigate how information about Coronavirus (COVID-19) influences prejudices towards foreign nationalities, especially the Chinese.

q4.value: We will also exploratorily examine whether receiving information about Coronavirus (COVID-19) increases prejudice toward Hungarians (familiar group with no diagnosed cases of the virus) and Mongolians (unfamiliar group with no diagnosed cases of the virus).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Between and within subject design. 

All participants will be invited to take part in a study, which consists of two independent studies. The first study includes rating short press reports, and the second study includes a questionnaire regarding the attitudes towards different nationalities.

There will be two experimental groups. In both groups, participants will receive three press media reports. In the first group, participants will receive two neutral texts and one text about climate change. In the second group, participants will receive two neutral texts, and one text about Coronavirus (COVID-19).
All participants will be asked to rate the quality of given press reports. 

In the second part, all participants will be presented with the same questions, regarding attitudes towards four nationalities (i.e. Hungarian, Italian, Mongolian, and Chinese) – presented in a random order.

 At the end, participants will provide information regarding basic socio-economic measures.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two experimental groups (i.e. two neutral press reports and one press report about climate change, or two neutral press reports and one press report about Coronavirus). Moreover, the order of the questions about attitudes towards the four nationalities (i.e. Hungarian, Italian, Mongolian, and Chinese) in the second part of the study will be randomized (e.g., some participants will be presented at first with the questions about the Hungarians, then with the questions about the Mongols, then Italians, and lastly with the questions about the Chinese, whereas other participants will be presented at first with the questions about the Chinese, then with the questions about the Italians, then Hungarians, and lastly with the questions about the Mongols, etc.).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
354 participants will be recruited with the help of an external survey company. Participants will be compensated for the participation.

Participants will be asked to participate in two ostensibly unrelated studies. After providing an informed consent for participation, participants will be presented with three short press reports (either two neutral and one about climate change, or two neutral and one about Coronavirus). Their task will be to rate the quality of the given press reports. We will not analyze the ratings of the press reports’ quality, as the goal of the first part of the study is to merely present participants with either a press report about Coronavirus or not.
This manipulation will be followed by attention check (we will ask participants a question single choice question regarding the content of each press report). 

In the second part of the study, participants will provide answers on their attitudes towards the four nationalities (i.e. Hungarians, Italians, Mongolians, and Chinese), presented in a random order.

A short questionnaire about basic socio-economic measures will be placed at the end of the study.

q14.value: Using G*Power we determined that we need 272 participants in order to obtain a power of 80%, with alpha .05 to detect effect of f =  .1 (F tests, ANOVA: Repeated measures, within-between interaction). We will deliberately overshoot this number by 30 percent due to expected missing data.

question.value:
1)	The first group will receive the following press reports:
[Participants will respond on a 1-7 Likert scale (ranging from 1 – ‘I completely agree’ to 7 – ‘I completely disagree’)]

The new giant in Amazon
The new tallest tree in Amazon has been recently discovered. It is 88 meters (289 ft) tall, moreover, it is 50% taller than the previously considered as the tallest, Amazon’s tree. Although the tallest tree has been discovered between 2016 and 2018 by the Brazil’s National Institute for Space Research, in a coordinated project, during which the large swaths of the Amazon has been scanned, only recently the team of researchers actually measured the tree and claimed its title. Nevertheless, the ‘giant’ from Amazon is yet far behind the tallest tree in the world – Hyperion, from California, which is stated to be of 115.85 meters (380 ft) tall. Interestingly, the exact locations of those high kings are shrouded in mystery to prevent potential vandalism.

1.	The press report is interesting and riveting.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

2.	The vocabulary of the press report is understandable.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

3.	The press report addresses socially relevant issues.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

Can you fold my laptop please
An international team of researchers has announced a new development that can change the way our laptops work, and look like. The recent trend in mobile technology, which easily spread and conquered the 2019 tech market, was based on a simple idea – to allow users to fold their devices. Foldable mobile phones have won the hearts of many people, thus, it is not surprising that the next step must have been to create foldable laptops. Thanks to the innovative solutions, a 17-inch laptop with a touchscreen became a reality. Its designers hope that the laptop will pass the initial tests successfully, and the mass production and distribution will be possible before the end of June.

1.	The press report is interesting and riveting.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

2.	The vocabulary of the press report is understandable.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

3.	The press report addresses socially relevant issues.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

Coronavirus – modern Black Death?
The novel coronavirus COVID-19 is now causing panic all around the world. It started in Wuhan, and as of the beginning of March, there have been more than 100 000 cases with a suspected disease, among which almost 4 000 people have died already. More dreadfully, among the victims of the viruse are doctors, who – despite the danger, put their life at great risk and willingly take care of sick patients. But the Coronavirus takes no prisoners and has no mercy. Many compare it to the Black Death, which in the medieval Europe led to deaths of millions of people. Will the Coronavirus become a modern plague with such an unimaginable death rate, reaching up to 40% of the entire human population?

1.	The press report is interesting and riveting.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

2.	The vocabulary of the press report is understandable.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

3.	The press report addresses socially relevant issues.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

b)	A recently discovered species of ants

a)	Nanotechnology
b)	Newest iPad
c)	Foldable laptops

The third press report was about:
a)	Anti-vaccine movement 
b)	Outbreak of Coronavirus 
c)	Novel cancel treatment

Although the tallest tree has been discovered between 2016 and 2018 by the Brazil’s National Institute for Space Research, in a coordinated project, during which the large swaths of the Amazon has been scanned, only recently the team of researchers actually measured the tree and claimed its title. Climate change – will mankind become extinct?
Scientists from all around the world are in an agreement that climate change is a fact. The average temperatures are now rising faster than at many other times in the past. Ice is melting, and most glaciers are retrieving. This may lead not only to severe droughts in some regions, but also intense rainfalls in others. Such places as Venice could sink, and others may be at great risk of massive floods. Many predict that the devastating floods in XX century may happen again, and as a consequence, millions of people would die. Some even say that the death rate connected with climate change could reach up to 40% of the entire human population.

1.	The press report is interesting and riveting.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

2.	The vocabulary of the press report is understandable.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

3.	The press report addresses socially relevant issues.
1 – I completely agree
7 – I completely disagree

d)	A recently discovered tree in Amazon
e)	A recently discovered species of ants
f)	The deepest lake in the world

The second press report was about:
d)	Nanotechnology
e)	Newest iPad
f)	Foldable laptops

The third press report was about:
a)	Climate change
b)	Neanderthals in Africa
c)	Archeological findings in Ethiopia

We will measure attitudes towards four nationalities (i.e. Hungarian, Italian, Mongolian, and Chinese), using Bogardus (1925; 1933) scale, which consists of three questions (i.e. whether participants would accept a member of a given group as a co-worker, as a neighbor, and as part of their family). Responses range from 1 (‘definitely wouldn’t mind’) to 7 (‘definitely would mind’). There will be, in total nine questions (three questions per each nationality):

Would you mind if an Italian was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Italians were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married an Italian? 

Would you mind if a Hungarian was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Hungarians were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married a Hungarian? 

Would you mind if a Chinese was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Chinese people were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married a Chinese? 

Would you mind if a Mongolian was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Mongolians people were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married a Mongolian?


The order of the presented nationalities will be randomized.

We will average the scores across the three questions to obtain a single measure of prejudice towards the Hungarians, Italians, Mongolians, and the Chinese.

We will use mixed ANOVA 2 (condition: neutral and climate change press reports vs neutral and coronavirus press reports – between) x 4 (prejudices towards nationalities: Hungarian, Italian, Mongolian, and Chinese – within) to analyze our results.

q22.value: We will exclude data from participants who will not pass the attention check.

q24.value: We do have directional hypothesis regarding the shift in attitudes toward Italians and Chinese but not regarding Mongolians and Hungarians. We will exploratorily examine the effect of information about the virus on prejudice towards them.

2)	The second group will receive the following press reports:
The new giant in Amazon
The new tallest tree in Amazon has been recently discovered. It is 88 meters (289 ft) tall, moreover, it is 50% taller than the previously considered as the tallest, Amazon’s tree. Although the tallest tree has been discovered between 2016 and 2018 by the Brazil’s National Institute for Space Research, in a coordinated project, during which the large swaths of the Amazon has been scanned, only recently the team of researchers actually measured the tree and claimed its title. Nevertheless, the ‘giant’ from Amazon is yet far behind the tallest tree in the world – Hyperion, from California, which is stated to be of 115.85 meters (380 ft) tall. Interestingly, the exact locations of those high kings are shrouded in mystery to prevent potential vandalism.

Can you fold my laptop please
An international team of researchers has announced a new development that can change the way our laptops work, and look like. The recent trend in mobile technology, which easily spread and conquered the 2019 tech market, was based on a simple idea – to allow users to fold their devices. Foldable mobile phones have won the hearts of many people, thus, it is not surprising that the next step must have been to create foldable laptops. Thanks to the innovative solutions, a 17-inch laptop with a touchscreen became a reality. Its designers hope that the laptop will pass the initial tests successfully, and the mass production and distribution will be possible before the end of June.

Climate change – will mankind become extinct?
Scientists from all around the world are in an agreement that climate change is a fact. The average temperatures are now rising faster than at many other times in the past. Ice is melting, and most glaciers are retrieving. This may lead not only to severe droughts in some regions, but also intense rainfalls in others. Such places as Venice could sink, and others may be at great risk of massive floods. Many predict that the devastating floods in XX century may happen again, and as a consequence, millions of people would die. Some even say that the death rate connected with climate change could reach up to 40% of the entire human population.

registration_responses.q17.question:
We will measure attitudes towards four nationalities (i.e. Hungarian, Italian, Mongolian, and Chinese), using Bogardus (1925; 1933) scale, which consists of three questions (i.e. whether participants would accept a member of a given group as a co-worker, as a neighbor, and as part of their family). Responses range from 1 (‘definitely wouldn’t mind’) to 7 (‘definitely would mind’). There will be, in total nine questions (three questions per each nationality):

Would you mind if an Italian was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Italians were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married an Italian? 

Would you mind if a Hungarian was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Hungarians were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married a Hungarian? 

Would you mind if a Chinese was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Chinese people were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married a Chinese? 

Would you mind if a Mongolian was working in the same place as you?
Would you mind if Mongolians people were living in your neighborhood?
Would you mind if someone from your family married a Mongolian?


The order of the presented nationalities will be randomized.

We will average the scores across the three questions to obtain a single measure of prejudice towards the Hungarians, Italians, Mongolians, and the Chinese.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will use mixed ANOVA 2 (condition: neutral and climate change press reports vs neutral and coronavirus press reports – between) x 4 (prejudices towards nationalities: Hungarian, Italian, Mongolian, and Chinese – within) to analyze our results.
